div1.p: Truby offers observations on Lazear, Moran, and Kissinger.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, October 10, 1940
div1.opener:
I have much
to add to my
story when
it is re-written.
Am sorry it
is in such
bad shape.
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
Oct- 10/40
Dear Dr- Hench:
div1.p:
Your telegram came this a. m.
and I thought an answer by air mail
would be more satisfactory than a telegram.
There is no risk that I can see about
returning it and if you desire to keep
it until you leave for W. & J. you may
do so. If you have any comments
why not write them on the m. m. s. as
Gen. Kean did. I am sorry he did not
answer more of my questions, but I
think he was overwhelmed by your m m s.
& questionaires and mine all coming
at about the same time.

You may use anything you desire
about Dr. Lazear I feel that I was
directly responsible for Lazear's coming
to Cuba as I appealed to our Chief
Surgeon (Kean) for help in our laboratory
during the epidemic of Dengue in
the Fall of '99. No one was available
for that work in Cuba and the request
for a bacteriologist went on to the S. Gx
Lazear presumably had asked for service
in the Army and was therefore available
for duty in Cuba.

My plans are to send the m m s. to others,
including Dr- Cooke, for their comment
on anything they may consider doubtful
or inaccurate. In this way I hope that
the data will have some claim to
accuracy. Much of it is, I know, quite
reliable- Dr Cooke should be able to confirm
many of the details. Many thanks for his
address- I have had a letter from
Kissinger and I am surprised at the
change that has taken place in him.
Is he Senile? He was a bright boy
and one of our most reliable men.
In volunteering he was ahead of Moran
by at least a day or two, but I have
no data on that point- Moran did not
belong to our Columbia Bks. detatchment
and that explains why he knew so little
about the landmarks when you were with
him on the ground. In April 1937 I had
a letter from Moran about the identity
of the men in the Detatchment Photo. He
was no help whatever and I am wondering
how he knows that no. 14 is Jernegan,
and no. 40 is Weatherwalks? I want to
get the list straight and will eventually
do so. Kissinger does not think that 14
is Jernegan, but I think it is-

I will be glad to get your comment
on the Confidential correspondence I had with Kean
I am feeling fine again and can promptly
handle any comments or questions re my paper.
Sorry I can't be at the W & J exercises and meet my old
friends. My retired pay restricts my activities in that respect.
